title: Integration – Building Peaceful Sentences with Prepositions (Ablative)
goals: Use Ablative prepositional phrases in full sentences
Contrast motion and rest in meaning and grammar
Reflect on peace as harmony – Pax

steps.speak: Salve! Welcome to Week 15 Day 3. Yesterday we practiced resting in our phrases — today we’ll build full peaceful sentences.
Let’s recall our Ablative prepositions: in, sub, cum, ē/ex, dē. They show rest, relationship, or origin.
Repeat after me: Puella sedet in hortō – The girl sits in the garden.
Puer habitat cum amīcō – The boy lives with a friend.
Agricola est sub arbore – The farmer is under the tree.
Sacerdōs venit ē templō – The priest comes out of the temple.
Now compare: Agricola ambulat in agrum (into the field – motion) vs. Agricola est in agrō (in the field – rest).
Mini quiz: Which endings show rest?
Faith phrase: Cum Deō ambulāmus – We walk with God. True peace means walking rightly, not rushing wrongly.
Virtue reflection: Peace doesn’t erase motion — it aligns it with rest. Both belong together in order.
Optime! Tomorrow we’ll master both motion and rest together.
